Belgia. 1591 24 Novem
b
To my L Trea
s
Belgia: 1591. No
v
May it please yo
r
good L. sins
e writing of
my letter of
e 16 of this moneth, wherein I gave
yo
w
to understand of
D. Cassimires
message to
some special persons in this place, about
e mater
of Pacification, there is nowe
at letter come hi-
ther, w
ch
, as then I advertised, was expected
every day to
e
General states
. Many men
heere dislike it utterly, as if it were full of
evident and inward tokens of his earnest incli-
nation to second
e
Emper
or
:
whereby they are
persuaded
at he is wonne unto it by a pension,
or by somwhat in reward, wherein
e Spaniard,
it is thought, will use any practise to speede of
his purpose. His letter was written in
highe dutche, wherof I send yow
e copie heer-
inclosed, w
t
e Frenche translation. It was
delivered heere to some of
Holland;
of those that
are deputed to open all suche letters, as are sent
unto
e states. Howbeit as yet they have ne-
ther thought it expedient, to acquaint the Pro-
vinces w
t
it, nor to impart it w
t
this
Councel.
It hath bin read but by some fewe, who are
bent to suppresse it, and, for ought I can per-
ceave, to make no answear at all. What
course I shall folowe for mine owne endevo
rs
, while
this mater is in motion, I attend to be instructed
by yo
r
L. letters.
For I knowe not well by yo
r
last yo
r
L. intent. It seemeth as if yo
w
could
have liked, that
e states should have sent to have
treated at
Collen.
But it can not be perfour-
med, w
t
out
e privitie and allowance, and some

re

o

Belgia: 1591: No
v
special Commission from every Province in parti-
cular.
All that I am affraid of is that if
e generallitie
And if once
e vulgar people shall be
of this c
o
trey should be brought unto a Treaty
brought to a Treaty, it is greatly to be feared,
that
suche conditions may be embraced, upon
some passion of
e people, and by some practise
of
e Spaniard, as may prejudice greatly both
themselves and their neighbo
rs
. Heere
goeth a speeche,
at
e
D. of Parma
is returned
from
e frontiers of
France
to
Brussels:
as
some men report, to conferre w
t
e Empero
rs
Ambassado
rs
: but as other men affirme, upon
intelligence receaved,
at his government was
conferred
bestowed
upon
e old
Count Mansfeld
. How-
soever, it should seeme by all advertisments,
at he is fallen in great disgrace w
t
e Spanishe
Kinge. If
e
comissary Sparhawke
doe his diligence,
hav
i
g had his dispatche
e 22 of this moneth,
I trust
e companies required
for
e service of
Rouen
will be there,
e winde
serving,
w
t
in these five or six daies
about
e end of this moneth.
